reviewText: It seemed a long time before this one finally came out and I could at last, complete my collection. I will say that it was worth the wait, because a few of my favorite episodes were in the last season. Yes, they were silly and mostly camp for the most part, still, it was interesting to at last catch some of the scenes that were cut away to make room for those annoying late night commercials. It was a fun program, and it was memorable to me as I was a fan of it in its heyday.While the effects were haphazard the stars were top notch, and they are missed.It's still fun to pop some corn and suspend my belief and just enjoy myself.

reviewText: A friend of mine  had seasons 1,2 On DVD... Asked me if I wanted them.. Took them and started to watch them. I am hooked.. Got season 3, and part of 4. And looking to get Vol 2 of season 4..WEll I have them all now. Season 4 is going down hill. Cost cutting. And it got hit just like Lost in Space did. Cost Cutting... one more great show, gone.... . Great fun show. Voyage was a great TV show. Not like the trash that is on now. I have all of Lost in Space, Time Tunnel,I Dream of Jeannie, Mission Impossible, The X files, The Outer Limits, Star Trek, Gilligan's Island. Sanford and Son, Walker Texas Ranger, Star Gate, SG-1.  and more. The Old TV shows are King! I do watch House, CSI Miami, and Fringe. but about 98% of the stuff on TV is TRASH!!!And Cable TV is on the way out here in my house!!!!Have Netflix... And my DVD's and Hulu +... All I need....Be well...

reviewText: I found this final DVD release of "Voyage" a whole two weeks and two days early on the shelves at a DVD store in the mall and I grabbed it instantly. Again, as with the previous releases of this series, the video looks FANTASTIC! I checked out one of my all-time favorite episodes, "The Man Beast" and it looked great, crisp with vivid colors. It was nice to see a longer scene of Captain Crane examining himself in the mirror which the Sci-Fi Channel always edited out. I also checked out the unaired pilot with original commercials and saw commercials for Breck shampoo and a no-longer-made deoderant called "Fresh" as well as others. It took me back to the sixties with these black and white commercials. Both the unaired and aired pilots are presented in black and white. The color cover is different than the one Amazon presents as the image of David Hedison is not the same as pictured on Amazon but the rest of it including the image of Richard Basehart is the same. The price I paid was $32.99 and I am sure it will be priced similarly or even lower in a lot of places including right here on Amazon. I was so pleased to set this DVD set of season four volume two alongside my others in this set and finally complete the voyage. Most people who read this review will realize this was an imaginative TV series which ran for four years in the sixties and all but the first season are in color. The journey of the submarine Seaview and its crew is well worth taking. This is a must-have for "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea" fans. Ahoy!

reviewText: Though Voyage still remains an innovating series, the episodes on this set gave me the impression the show was running out of steam. Richard Basehart and David Hedison  were still great to watch, but the second volume didn't seem to take off as well as the first one. The writing started to become a collection of recycled themes and off the wall plots. On the good side there were a few repeat appearances from the likes of Henry Jones, Skip Homeier, Kevin Hagen and Malachi Throne. Walter Burke made an unusually big leprechaun, but he pulled it off well enough to keep the show interesting. All in all, the show held up well over time and the picture quality is great. The more I think of it, if I compare any season of this show to what's on TV nowadays, it wins by a landslide.
summary: The best of season four was the first 13 episodes

reviewText: I know I'm a little late with this review, but I am delighted that "VOYAGE TO THE BOTTOM OF THE SEA:  Season 4, Volume 2" has finally been released.  The episodes look and sound great.  Some of the "In Color" bumpers were included at the beginning of the episodes.  The alternate pilot with Theo Marcuse was great to see as well as the broadcast pilot with original commercials and sponser spots.  I also agree it is a shame that the shows were not totally complete with the "brought to you by..." and the scenes from next week, and that the packaging is different, episode information is minor, and that double-sided discs were used, but we should just be grateful that they finally did release the last of the episodes.  The sales of these series are obviously not that great and that's why they have been split into volumes and corners have been cut in the production of these collections.  It was a long wait for "Season 4, Volume 1"; 1 years, and then one month shy of two years for "Volume 2," but we made it.  Now, we have all four seasons and all 110 episodes of this classic Irwin Allen series to enjoy for years to come.

reviewText: This review is not so much for the series.  Fans of the show are well aware of the content, containing the infamous "Lobster Man" episode as well as the return of Mr. Pem (played by veteran character actor Henry Jones) in the series final entry as well as another airing of the UNAIRED pilot.The biggest complaint is Fox's lack of concern for those who remember the show from its initial airing, from 1964-1968, the ones who KNOW how it began and ended, including the opening theme with the line, "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea brought to you..."  The fact that Fox chose to omit "...brought to you by..." as well as the music as the opening radar sequence disappeared is truly an insult to the fan who has fond memories of it.Also, with David Hedison (Capt. Crane), Terry Becker (Chief Sharkey), Bob Dowdell (Commander Morton), and Richard Bull ("Doc") still among the living, it would have been great if they had been allowed to give some new insight into the making of the classic series.However, the compilation can be praised for allowing viewers to "play all" episodes contained on each side of the 3 two-sided discs.  That was not available in many of the preceding discs of the series.
summary: Fox still doesn't respect the show's fans!

reviewText: VTTBOTS still remains head & shoulders above many entertainment shows of today in its technical wizardry and special effects, which incorporrated real physical models built by model makers and Art Directors rather than CGI's, when TV was TV... Great show which lasted four years and was probably Irwin Allen's most successful before the advent of Lost in Space, Land of the Giants and Time Tunnel, which gave salute to the old cold war era of spy & mystery dramas. Sadly, the Seaview lost her way in successive seasons with monsters and lame plot lines ending the most successful of voyages by 1968. Excellent picture quality and engineering on these discs however makes them a 'must have' for Voyage enthusiasts to new generations alike who will find it just as appealing.
summary: Still sailing to the top raitings....
Title: N/A

reviewText: The american public has allways been infatuated with submarines. Just look at a list of submarine movies since WW1's Hell Below to the recently cancelled ABC series Last Resort. Then look at the who's who of actors and actresses that have appeared in these sub epics. Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea was based on a movie way ahead of it's time. What is surprising is there still is not a submarine like the Seaview in this series. We are close however. But what makes this 4 Season series so fascinating is it is STILL science fiction. Again why we have not seen an updated version boggles the mind. Maby we can't dream like we used to. The first season is in black and white and deals with mostly espionage. Not good at all. But unlike today's Last Resort seaview got a 2nd. season and the rest is history.

reviewText: This second set covers the last thirteen episodes of the fourth and final season (1967-1968) of "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea". Among other things, a brand new artisan popup: director Charles Rondeau who will achieve some of the best episodes ("Nightmare", "Secret of the Deep", "The Death Clock") and is also known for his input on many 1960's espionage series as "Mission: Impossible", "The Wild Wild West" and "The Man from U.N.C.L.E.".These are the four episodes "not" to miss by all means necessary:1. "Nightmare": Captain Crane finds himself alone on the Seaview except for a phantom crew that begins a countdown to fire nuclear missiles on Washington D.C.2. "Edge of Doom": an espionage plot whose saboteur is a well-known Seaview officer.3. "Secret of the Deep": an espionage plot guest starring Peter Mark Richman as a double agent.4. "The Death Clock": Captain Crane assassinates Admiral Nelson under the influence of a time machine and attends his military sea funeral. Music by Harry Geller.Time traveler Mr. Pem (Henry Jones) returns in "No Way Back" and meets again Admiral Nelson: the best of his two appearances and still directed by the same Robert Sparr from "The Wild Wild West".Following the theme of the season 3 offering "The Brand and the Beast" (the sequel to "Werewolf") in which Admiral Nelson is turned into a werewolf, "Man-Beast" , also written by William Welch, shows Captain Crane who undergoes a state of biological regression due to the side effects of an experimental gas used to fight the high pressure of the deep sea inside the diving bell: one of the favourite episodes of actor David Hedison and whose means of sea exploration makes a veiled reference to a season 1 entitled "The Condemned". Music by Leith Stevens.Find the list of episodes from this volume 2:"The Return of Blackbeard""The Terrible Leprechaun""The Lobster Man""Nightmare""The Abominable Snowman""Secret of the Deep""Man-Beast""Savage Jungle""Flaming Ice""Attack!""Edge of Doom""The Death Clock""No Way Back"*Options Updates:LANGUAGE SELECTION1. Audio:-English Mono-French Mono2. Subtitles:-English for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing-None3. CC (closed-captions):-Included
summary: VOYAGE #4, vol. 2: Back to season 2 again!
